subject: Self Care
title: Self-Compassion Across Cultures
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Self-Compassion Across Cultures.

hook.text: Buddhist monks practiced self-compassion for millennia. Western psychology discovered it in 2003. Ancient wisdom, new science.

buildup.text: In Buddhist tradition, compassion always includes the self. Western culture separated self-care from virtue.

discovery.text: Cross-cultural studies show self-compassion benefits every culture tested, though some resist it more than others.

twist.text: Cultures that value self-sacrifice often view self-compassion as weakness. The data shows the opposite is true.

climax.text: Self-compassion is universal. The practices may vary by culture, but the human need for self-kindness does not.

punchline.text: Every culture needs it. Not every culture teaches it yet.

quiz.question: Where did self-compassion practices originate before Western psychology?
options: Buddhist contemplative traditions practiced it for millennia
